}} 'Stari Ras' (; meaning Old Ras, old Latin name 'Arsa'), known at the time as
Ras, was one of the first capitals of the medieval Serbian state of RaÅ¡ka, and
the most important one for a long period of time. Located in today's region of
RaÅ¡ka, the city was right in the centre of the early medieval state that started
to spread in all directions. It was founded between 8th and 9th centuries and
got deserted sometime in the 13th century. Its favorable position in the area
known as Old Serbia, along the RaÅ¡ka gorge, on the crossroads between the
Adriatic Sea and state of Zeta, Bosnia in the west and Kosovo in the east added
to its importance as a city. There is an impressive group of medieval monuments
consisting of fortresses, churches and monasteries. The monastery at SopoÄani is
a reminder of the contacts between Western world and the Byzantine world. Today
the city lies in mostly unenclosed and unprotected ruins close to the city of
Novi Pazar, which probably began its own life as a trading enclave for Ras.
However, there are plans for future reconstruction of the site. The site of
Stari Ras, in combination with the nearby Monastery of SopoÄani, is already a
UNESCO World Heritage Site, and Stari Ras monastery (12th century) is being
reconstructed and it too may be included on the UNESCO World Heritage List with
the site. Stari Ras and SopoÄani World Heritage site is not far from another
UNESCO World Heritage Site of Serbia, the magnificent medieval monastery and
churches of Studenica. The 4th century Church of Saint Apostles Peter and Paul
is one of the oldest in the Balkans.

Stari Ras was declared Monument of Culture of Exceptional Importance in 1990,
and it is protected by Republic of Serbia.
